sp.p: Fled away in the dark, sir, with a young man of your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Villain, leave fooling.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: There's none in the case, sir—She never did wiser—had she staid your return, she had fallen into those clutches which will immediately gripe you, if you don't make off; Rosa has ran, till she had little breath left, to tell you the corregidor and alguazils are coming to apprehend all in this house—so save yourself, sir—she's safe enough—Antonio has taken her to a nunnery.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: A nunnery, slave!—there she's lost to me for ever—When once they are inform'd of these transactions—

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Be pacified, sir, it was so design'd, at first.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: But mym aster has convey'd her, sir, to his brother-in-law's, whose credit and quality are so eminent, that the engaging him in your mutual protection, he doubts not, will much avail you—My master's bride, too, will assist to comfort her—I was ordered to wait o'purpose to inform you this; and if you will venture to follow them, to assure you, you may depend on a protection there also. I have the key of my master's apartments to conduct you privately; and he intreats you will go in a chair, to avoid being question'd, in case of any encounter by the way.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My noble friend! with gratitude I embrace his counsel.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Hollo! up with your burden, beasts, and fall into your half trot [the chair brought, Florio gets into it]

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Heavens! we are all taken! sit still, sir, for your life.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: We have them safe.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: You find, sir, I was right.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Some of you search the house throughout: see what servants there are beside those in the hall. Be quick—we wait you here

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: This is one of Don Cupid's pretty jests: we are struck upon a rock before we put out to sea.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: What are you, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: A creature very like a man, sir, only I want a heart.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You're pleasant, sir—Pray Heav'n your mirth continue!—Who is that woman veil'd?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Let her answer for herself, if your worship pleases—She has a tongue; set it once a going, and she'll tell more than she knows.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Uncover her face.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: [to the Alguazil] Hold, friend!—Cousin, consider, should it be Honoria, 'twould be terrible to expose her here.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: 'Tis just—go, then, and speak in private to her.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: [to Juan, addressing her] 'Tis I, sir, Rosa, attending on my lady; I was commanded by her—

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Enough; I understand the rest, and pity her: bid her sit still; I'll do my best to save her from disgrace.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: A lucky mistake: it may save Florio from the officers. [Goes to the chair] They take you, for my mistress, sir, sit close; I'll follow, and watch all occasions for your escape.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: We have found our wandering nymph, sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Was that Honoria?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: No, sir; her waiting-woman Rosa, following the chair wherein they were conveying Honoria to some other place.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: We arrived luckily—had we staid a moment longer, they had all been fled.

sp.speaker: 1st. Alg.
sp.p: Should we see who's in the chair, sir?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No, forbear; the folly is punishment enough to a woman of her rank, without adding that of public disgrace—

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: How singularly happy it was, that you persuaded Don Henriquez to expect us at your house!—Had he been a witness to this discovery, his fury had transgressed all bounds.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: 'Tis true; and matters of this fort had better be reconciled by the mediation of friends, than either private resentments, or public trials—Who do you belong to, friend?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: To nobody.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Do not you serve?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: I did; but my master has lost himself—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Take his sword.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Pardon me, sir—I will surrender it.—I cou'd not bear to be disarm'd by any hand but my own;—This is a weapon, I'd have you to know, of such dreadful execution, that I dare not draw it, but at the call of justice.—Sir, as soon as you reach home, please to hang it up in your hall, and write under it,
sp.l: This is bold Guzman's sword; O may it be
Ever from rust, as 'tis from slaughter free!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Thou'rt a pleasant fellow.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p:
Faith, sir, I never make myself uneasy for love, riches, or reputation—nor do I pretend to that great sublety of sense, to feel before I am
hurt; and, for the most part, I keep out of harm's way—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: This fellow's an original.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: But of so ill a hand, sir, I am not worth hanging up among the worst of your worship's collection.
sp.stage: Enter Alguazils, with two Men and two Women Servants.

sp.speaker: 2d Alg.
sp.p: An't please your worship, we search'd the house from the cellar to the garrets, and these are all of the family to be found.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: These are most material—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Take special care of this varlet, and the waiting-woman; we'll have the truth from them I'll warrant.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Must we be prisoners together, Guzman?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: It's not so bad as the bands of wedlock, Rosa.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Hold! On reflection, we had better not carry Honoria home, till her brother's fury is abated; therefore, if you approve it, cousin, I'll take her to my house; as it is our desire to compose this business quietly, she will be in a kinsman's house with more decency and satisfaction, and will have, beside, my sister to accompany her; and further—

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: A lovely damsel they are bearing off!—some what hairy, 'tis true, about the chin, but that's a sign of strength. It tickles me to think how like an ass his worship will look, when he opens the shell, to find so rough a kernel.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And the lights too?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p:
Yes, and your officers—take them all off. I have two of Don Henriquez's servants; we shall be enough to guard our prisoners, and darkness will suit us best. The more privacy, the
safer will Honoria's reputation be. Cousin, good night.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You propose well, sir—this business could not be in better hands than your's—There I'll leave it, and wish you a good night.—Officers, follow me.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: You may go about your business, friends; I require none but these. Take up the chair, and follow these your guides.

head.stage: Scene changes to Honoria's Anti-chamber, in Henriquez's House.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now that we are safely arriv'd within these walls, madam, dismiss your fears; please to remain here till I bring lights, and acquaint Honoria with the happiness she will receive in entertaining so fair a guest.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Acquaint whom, sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My wife Honoria—a little patience—she will attend you.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Is her name Honoria, too? Heaven preserve her from such distresses as attend her namesake!—But where am I? so far from guessing the house, that, what with my fears, and darkness of the night, I can't conceive what quarter of the town it is: then we have taken so many turnings to avoid meeting my cruel brother, and his train;—but I trust in providence, I am now in a place out of his reach.
sp.stage: Enter ANTONIO with Lights; sets them on the Table.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I now go, madam, to fetch my wife; your pardon a moment.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p:
And if, as this friendly man flatters me,
I can but conciliate a friendship here—Save me! my brother's house!—this is the quarter joining to my own apartment—I cannot be mistaken—This the patronage and sarety I was promis'd!—false, false man—Yet to what end?—Why should he betray me? My Florio cou'd not mean—Oh, no, let me not think it—but that this man, who look'd like truth itself! to whom my Florio thought he could entrust his happiness and life—that he should be so base, to throw me into that danger it was my only care to shun!—All's over now—Struggling and hope alike are vain, and all my future life is misery.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Who can this lady be?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It is, I confess, madam, a liberty, which I perhaps ought not to take so early, but the distress of her situation will best apologize to your generous heart—The lady—but she can best relate her story; I will go seek Don Henriquez, and engage his power and interest in her behalf.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Madam, I—Heavn's—Honoria! Stay, stay Antonio—it is not fit Henriquez should be told—he's gone, and we are undone.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Antonio, said you cousin? what mean you?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Unlucky girl! you are fallen into your husband's hands—I have made such discoveries—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: O Heaven's!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: This is the man, to whom you are contracted; and, to aggravate our perplexities, the very hero, who preserv'd my life, and honour; tho', I begin to fear, at the expence of my happiness.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p:
His behaviour, and motives, then are well explain'd—The man, to whom I was engag'd, has been a witness to my concealment, my shame—my passion for another—and he has used this means
to bring me to my abandon'd home, that he and my unnatural brother, may wreak their cruel vengeance on me.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I am all amazement—How came you into his hands?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: My Florio, to whom he proves an intimate friend, entrusted me to his care; tho' till this moment, I never heard his name;—that might have alarm'd me—but every slightest circumstance concurs to ruin me.—

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: But were you distracted, to let him bring you here, or blind, not to know your own house?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: How could I in such darkness, such fear, such confusion? beside, he brought me in the back way, thro' his own quarter, and had the lights put out, before he introduc'd me—Well, I am prepar'd to suffer.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Not in such haste, my dear girl—while there is life there is hope—I'll struggle to the last moment—Don't you remember the mistake Antonio's servant made this afternoon?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Antonio' has done the same, in your absence; and, on your account, I did not disabuse him. He has renew'd his vows of love with equal ardour, as when he first saw me, and seem'd transported to discover his destin'd wife in the woman whom he rescued. There hangs your hope, and mine.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Vain suggestion! What hope can we have, while this cruel contract remains such a bar to our general happiness?—Besides, he has seen my brother by this time—the whole is out—and ruin certain.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Not so very certain, as you apprehend. Antonio's friendship to Florio, which induc'd him to-protect you, may yet—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p:
Friendship! dear Felicia, will that remain unshaken?—will that stand up against these strange
events?—against the affront done to his honour? Oh! no—He is not what he was,—his mind, his principles are changed, and I am made the victim to his wrath—

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Antonio change! It is impossible. Tho' all felicity this world affords should bribe him, it could not tempt him to recede from his pledg'd faith, and honour.—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I forgot her interest in him.—Pardon me, my dear Felicia. I scarce know what I say. My mind is wounded by the variety of my afflictions.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: My lovely girl!—excuse my warmth—but I must repeat my assertions—If we have yet a chance for happiness, 'tis founded in his steadiness and truth—The more I contemplate it, the more do my spirits and hopes revive. If you cou'd secure yourself from your brother, this night only, what between my hero and brother—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: But where secure myself?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Steal home with me.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: By the secret door, thro' which you have so often pass'd, to meet your Florio—when last we used it, it was fatal; now it may be fortunate. Once escaped, get my brother's assent for this night's concealment, and ask his further advice, and assistance. I'll answer for him; he is generous, and kind—My lover brave and wise—dry your eyes; O'my credit, you shall not weep, till you have more occasion.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: He's here again, cousin.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Suppose we undeceive him—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Undeceive him!—

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Yes—such a confidence, I am sure, must rivet him to our interests.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: For heaven's sake, be cautious. I yet have doubts of his conduct.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I have none. Our hopes in him will be made certainties hereby.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: You'll infallibly repent it—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Not yet return'd!—A guest in his house too, that's come so far on such a business! something I can't comprehend—I have not yet been able, madam, to find your brother; but think it can't be long e'er he returns; then I'll inform him of the accident, which has made his house this lady's sanctuary.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: He persists in his mistake, I see.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: 'Tis now time, Don Antonio, to inform you—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I cou'd not wait at the corregidor's, tho' I promised; my impatience to unfold this riddle burns me up—that Don Antonio should entertain my sister when I was positive—By heav'n she's there, and Felicia with her!—were all my rascals mad, or was it a plot to insult me? and Don Juan! was he mad too? to swear he had trac'd her to another house? either I, or they, or all, must be possess'd—Some enchantment reigns here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Here is Don Henriquez—now I'll inform him, madam, of your sad story.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Undone utterly!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Don Henriquez—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I shall sink.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This lady, with your sister Honoria—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I know her well, sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Then you will the easier excuse my boldness.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: In what, sir?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Now it comes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That I have been the occasion of your finding her here, at this late hour.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I understand you, sir; she is desirous to pass this night, with Honoria, and assist her in ordering her nuptial ceremonies.—Ay, in heav'n's name, let her stay.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Better than I expected. Courage cuz!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But, sir, the necessity, that induces me to—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Dear sir, can you suppose an apology necessary for Honoria, and her kinswoman, passing a night together?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is she so near a relation of his? 'tis well I told no more of her story.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: She knows, I owe her for many favours, and hope to be able to repay them amply.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: There—can he speak his design much plainer?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: For that matter, the cap would fit me, as well as you.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Since it is so late, sir, will you give the ladies leave to retire, for the present, to their own chamber? withdraw, Honoria.—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Now Felicia!—

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I don't like this sudden calm—'tis but the fore-runner of another storm; let us fly to shelter.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: But how, while they remain in the Aside. room, thro' which we must pass?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: We must watch their departure—'tis probable, he'll wait on Antonio to his apartment, and we may take that opportunity to escape.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I will now go see whether Sancho has yet brought Florio to my apartment. Aside. your pardon, sir, I will but step to my own chamber, and return immediately.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Shall I conduct you, sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I know the way, I thank you, sir.—[There's something strange in his words, and behaviour, which indicates disguise and artifice. I must see it expounded.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: All the feinds in hell, sure, cou'd not conjure up such another mystery. Juan affirms the people, we fought with, had convey'd Honoria away—when I come to seek her, at home, she's missing, and her waiting wench tells me she went into the garden, whence no one knows of her return. Antonio, just after, protests he saw, and entertain'd her in her own apartment, where I certainly now find her, and that ungrateful woman with her.—These are riddles to pose an Oedipus, and madden a stoick—They must be explain'd, and shall—Yet hold! Antonio said he would return forthwith—here will I wait, 'till he arrives; see him safe at rest, and then extort the whole truth from Honoria.—Could I but be convinced my honour were yet unstain'd, I should, I think, be somewhat easier. The load might be a little lighter, that's all I'm to expect;
No hope of perfect, or of lasting rest,
While unrequited love corrodes the breast.

div3.head: SCENE, JUAN's House.
div3.stage: Enter JAQUES, with GUZMAN, ROSA, and FLORIO in the Chair.

sp.speaker: JAQUES.
sp.p: DAME Rosa, and brother servitor, in there; and now, my friends, open the chair, and let the lady out.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: By the darkness, this is the condemn'd dungeon, and when we are led out, it will be to execution.

sp.speaker: Jaques.
sp.p: Away, friends; you shall be paid below.
sp.stage: [Exit with the Chair, and locks the Door.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.p: What miserable den am I thrust into?—Rosa—Guzman—

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: I'm here, sir—and Rosa close to me, or I have lost my sense of feeling—one drop just to keep up my spirits—

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Booby!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I can't conjecture where we are; I did not dare look out; but wheresoe'er, 'tis better than in the corregidor's hands.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: I am as much at a loss as you, sir—the moon clouding, and our quick pace prevented my observing the turnings.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: I wish they wou'd give us a little light, that we might see whether there was any means of running away, or no. I spy a glimmering under the door; the key turns—I'll venture to secure the candle however.
sp.stage: [He gets on one side of the door—Jaques entering with a candle, he seizes it.

sp.speaker: Jaques.
sp.p: Don Florio!
sp.stage: [Jaques seeing Florio, starts, runs off quick, and double-locks the door.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: We're fast again; we've got a light however, and may see what kind of place we are in!

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Thanks to Don Guzman! I always held stratagem in war, preferable to force.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: As I live, sir, we are in Don Juan's house.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Heaven forbid!

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: I'm sure, sir; I have frequented it too often, on Cupid's errands, when you and my mistress us'd to meet in Donna Felicia's apartment, to be mistaken in any part of it.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: 'Tis too truly so; our enemies will soon know whom they have entangled in their snares, and then their malicious designs will be compleated.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Stay, I think we have some room to hope—beyond that inner chamber, there is a backstair-case, if the door be but open; it always us'd—let's try, sir.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Lead on, guide.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p:
Not yet retunr'd! what an irksome situation to a man of my anxious disposition! in momentary expectation of Antonio, therefore not daring to enquire into what so intimately concerns my peace and honour; no, I must not attempt an explanation with my sister, 'till the house be quiet, and Antonio retir'd to rest. Shou'd he overhear any part of it, he wou'd reject her hand with scorn.—What strange circumstances have join'd together to prevent that single and only event, which might give
me ease!—their marriage—'tis one comfort however, that I have her safe now; I have not quitted these apartments; she cannot have made a second garden-excursion—Therefore, till I can settle the whole affair to my wishes, I will endeavour to subdue my temper, controul my feelings, and be no more under the dominion of such passions, as rend my heart.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Why wou'd Don Henriquez leave the corregidor's, before I—Oh! he's here,—yet how shall I tell it him? Don Henriquez—I—I—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: What, Don Juan? Why this hesitation?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: I dread to tell the issue of our search.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: You need not, my friend; some favourable circumstances, and a little cool reflection, I trust, have render'd me more temperate.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: I shou'd rejoice to prove it: but when you have heard my story, I fear you will relapse.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Cousin, I've said it—I will not—

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: The corregidor and myself just reach'd the appointed place, time enough for his officers to seize the servants, who were accomplices, when they were just going to convey away in a chair—I cannot speak it—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Out with it, man—conveying away whom?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Even so.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Oh! ho! ho! ho!

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Do you laugh, cousin? You are indeed chang'd in temper when the honour of our family is a subject for your mirth.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Honoria! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: This is a worse extreme, methinks, than t'other; your senses are unsettled.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: You're not in earnest?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: I am—I found her there, as sure as you have life.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Why 'tis not possible—Antonio entertain'd Honoria here, even now, accompanied by your sister; and even now I left them within, sent her to her chamber myself.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Cousin, cousin, what motive can you have for endeavouring to impose on me? I tell you positively I found her there, and her waiting-woman Rosa with her.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Cousin, cousin, do not persist thus to affirm impossibilities.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Sure you are making some experiment on my temper; are endeavouring to provoke me to one of your own frantick fits, that I may never dare to counsel you again; I swear to you, upon my honour, 'tis not half an hour since I left Honoria bearing away in a chair from the house, to which I dogg'd her, and your man Jaques leading the way, and guarding Rosa.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: And I swear to you, upon my honour, and the honour of our whole ancestry, 'tis not a quarter of an hour, since I spoke with Honoria, and your sister, in this very apartment.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Indeed, Don Henriquez—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: It may be decided this moment; follow me to her.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: O! sir, I have such admirable news, yet am so full of astonishment, I scarce have power to tell you.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Villain, dispatch.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: When I had convey'd madam Honoria—

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: See! I told you so—

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Rosa, and the man-servant who was with them, to your house, I lock'd 'em all three into your antichamber, and went down for a light.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: This madness is infectious, and my varlet is in one of Juan's fits.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: With which when I return'd, who shou'd I see, but Don Florio in the middle of the room, and madam Honoria vanish'd.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: How is that possible, if you are sure you lock'd the door, when you went to fetch candles?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Ay, that's the very point, sir; that I can't tell—but—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: No matter, you are sure you have Florio there?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: I'll forfeit my life on that, sir.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: My injuries rekindle at his name; this moment will I sacrifice the author of my shame, and inquietude.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Is then your promis'd coolness—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Away; I will not be advis'd, nor controul'd: the beast is in the toil, and he shall die.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Who is the unhappy man, brother, you so severely doom? And what the great offence to honour, which life alone can answer?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Sir—I—I—I am a villain if I know what to say to him;—how spiteful is his coming at this moment!

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: His appearance just now is critically happy; I may, by his aid, assuage, at least, if not o'er-rule this madness.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Consider me already as a friend, and brother, and as such treat me; give me a knowledge of your wrongs—I have a sword ready to serve in all occasions worthy yourself and me.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: This affair, sir, is so unfit—so unluckily tim'd, and your arrival here—it makes—how shall I shake him off?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Noble Don Antonio, if you value your brother's honour, persist in accompanying him; I have most weighty reasons, which when you know, you cannot but approve.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Wrong me not, Don Henriquez, by suspicion: prove, by this early trial of my truth, how heartily I mean, thro' life, to espouse the happiness, and interests of your family.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I cannot doubt your honour, bravery, or attachment to our house; but, to engage so dear a guest in any cause of danger were inhospitable.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Be what it may, let me partake it; you are too noble to employ your sword in an unworthy cause; therefore I must, I will attend you, or you, by your distrust, prevent our promis'd union.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Not knowing, sir, the nature of those injuries, whereon my resentments are grounded, you may perhaps wonder at my desperate measures.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You are too good a judge of honour's dues, to pursue such measures, as will not bear a friend's inspection.—We go, sir——

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: To witness my revenge—Lights there.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Sir, suffer him not to quit your sight, I beg: and use all means to calm his rage; I'll follow instantly. [Exit Ant.] Let me reflect a moment;—if Honoria be there (as sure she must) heaven knows to what extremes Henriquez may be driven!—Florio, at least, is there, and I have ignorantly been the means of throwing him into his enemy's power; 'tis therefore incumbent on me, while he has the sanction of my house, to endeavour to preserve his life, tho' at the hazard of my own.

div3.head: SCENE, the Chamber in Don JUAN's House.
div3.stage: FLORIO, ROSA, and GUZMAN discover'd: Chairs, Table, and the Candle.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: How thwart and provoking?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: That unlucky door!—I never knew it shut before.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: We have now no means, Rosa; my dangers and distresses are compleat! I must welcome and endure them. Yet shall not my desperate state make me neglect the only duty I can pay;—the amiable, the generous Felicia's reputation must not be left in doubt, even with the base Henriquez, whose cruel temper has form'd suspicions unworthy of her blameless conduct; 'tis fit I set him right.
sp.stage: [Sits down to write in his Tablets.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: A curse on all love! and a double curse on all constant love! 'tis always attended with fatal disasters! or ends in the worst of all, marriage.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: I suppose you wish every body to have such a quicksilver heart, as yours: that can settle no where.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Why, that wou'd not be amiss for you, my dear Rosa; you might then hope to have your turn, as well as pretty fac'd damsels.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: And you wou'd be one of the last, I shou'd hear of; yet 'tis possible you might come, before you were welcome.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p:
She has wit, and good humour; excellent ingredients to pass away time; I have a liking to her person too, but that will end with marriage, and possibly her good humour too;—well, honest Guzman, I wou'd advise you to be wary; if you shou'd couple yourself to a yoke, instead of a yokefellow, you'll wear it to your grave.
Yet, on recollection, your dancing days are now over; your pleasures are come up to your mouth, you are now for the comfortable joys of life, ease, and eating. And there's no cook or dry-nurse like a wife.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Rosa, shou'd aught but well befal me, give these with care to Don Henriquez' hands—either on his desperate arm, or his black testimony at the bar, my life depends; no matter which way 'tis decided.
sp.stage: Enter HONORIA, and FELICIA, thro' a private Door.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I think no creature saw us pass thro' the apartments.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: What a tedious while have we been kept, before they left the chamber! My Florio too! what is become of him? The rage, we perceiv'd even now my brother to be in, makes me tremble, lest, by some strange means, he, as well as myself, may be thrown into his power.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: My dearest mistress!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Oh! heavens!

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Florio! then my fears were true.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Can I trust my senses?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: I think not, we are asleep, and dreaming, or haunted by fairies.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: How is it possible I find you here? Did not my noble friend undertake your protection?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: So did he yours, yet you are here, and equally expos'd to ruin.—Oh! how I grieve to say, 'tis he that has betray'd us both!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Antonio betray us!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Oh! no.—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: It is, too surely—he is the man, to whom my brother has contracted me.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p:
Bless my stars! no wonder we have blunder'd so, when we contriv'd to take a husband into
our party; nothing can succeed, they are concern'd in.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Contracted to Honoria! he come to marry my Honoria.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: The very same, and he has taken these ungenerous means, to sacrifice us both.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I will not, cannot think it; I would as soon believe impossibilities, as his apostacy from honour.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What's her concern in him Honoria?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: That adds to our distresses—she, and Antonio—

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: This is no time to relate adventures—Florio and you must not be found here; therefore, Rosa, take this key, and set open the garden door, that leads to St. Jerome's street, thro' that you may easily escape, on the least alarm.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Make haste, dear girl.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Generous Felicia!

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: My lovely girl, under what obligations—how now Rosa! What's the matter?—

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Undone past hope! your brother, Antonio, Juan, and servants, with swords drawn, are, at this instant, in the hall: what will you do?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Into this inner room; retire, my love, and let me meet their rage.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I cannot leave you—let me but stay, and share your fate—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I have no fears, but for you; nay haste; I must compel you to the only means of safety, and concealment.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Oh! if that's your scheme, the devil take the hindmost! 'tis for your sake, Rosa, I shun these honourable engagements;—having lost my weapon, the best, I can do, is to walk off with the baggage.
sp.stage: Enter HENRIQUEZ, JUAN, ANTONIO, JAQUES, and GERALDO, with Lights.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I will not be persuaded.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Cousin, you must: I have an honour too to guard, dear to me as yours is to you; in all, that justice sanctifies, will I tread step for step; but will not permit my house to be the scene of premeditated mischief, and revenge;—already they have stain'd these walls too deeply.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Such admonitions are too sacred, surely, to pass unregarded; Henriquez cannot be so lost—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I cannot be so lost to my own honour's calls, or nature's feeling, to listen to a cynic's cold advice. Where is the man whose insolence and folly has so far misled him—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Here is the man you seek.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: What do I see:

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Whom thou so basely hast betray'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My friend! my Florio!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No more thy friend, Antonio, but Florio, by thy perfidy betray'd, and thrown upon his fate—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Let me pass.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hold a moment!

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: What mean you? Is all your fervour in a brother's interest reduc'd to a mean parley with the foe? I'll right myself.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Cousin forbear; you shall not have your way; there lies some mystery conceal'd in this, which once unfolded, might perhaps reconcile the difference.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p:
It cannot be but by the sword; Antonio, hear me; if that the faith and friendship pledg'd to me want power to rouze you, let your own interest
and honour; that man, whom you protect from my resentment, has seconded his insolence to me, by foul attempts upon Honoria's honour.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I seek to wrong her honour! the parent of your black designs, and bitter enmity, ne'er yet invented a more hellish salshood; 'tis true, I have lov'd the virtuous Honoria—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How, sir?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: But with such spotless affection, such pure devotion, that she has recompenc'd my passion with esteem; has chain'd me to her service, and I will either live to call her mine, or perish in her cause.—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Distraction—daggers to my heart!—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Oh! has it rous'd you, sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Henriquez pause!—mitigate your fury for a moment.—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I will not—His life or mine must pay the insolence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hold, or thro' me you pass; I must be heard. That impious man from infancy have I call'd friend;—allow me but a minute's space, alone to question him about our mutual wrongs—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Antonio, do not trifle with me; mean you to let him escape?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, by name and honour; if I deal not in this business to your heart's wish, and honour's credit, my own life shall pay the forfeit.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Consent, Henriquez, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My heart is bleeding, while I speak—I am not us'd to sue; let me conjure you by your hopes of bliss, by all your dearest wishes, by our propos'd union, grant me this, or here our friendship ceases, and we meet no more.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Delay is agony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I will not keep you long.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What means Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Darest thou answer my demands?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I can, and justify myself, thou traitor to thy friend!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Lead to some other spot.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: This way, good cousin.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I will not long be dallied with; these keen sensations will not leave my heart, nor can my fury die.
sp.stage: Enter HONORIA, FELICIA, and ROSA—GUZMAN following.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I am frighted to death.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: At all events, let's follow, and see the result.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Let me go first, ladies, and watch their motions, I'll keep an excellent look-out, and alarm you, in case of extremity.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Be it so then; away!

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: There will be mischief soon.—Therefore, as my master has rudely left the ladies, the least I can do is to keep with 'em, and take care of 'em.

head.stage: Scene changes to the Hall of Don JUAN's House.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Give up my title! I never will renounce Honoria.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You must—she is so much mine, that none must boast pretensions to her, while I live—in saving you from mad Henriquez' sword, I have discharg'd the engagement friendship made; the injur'd husband now requires his dues.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Spite of my wrongs, I know not how to lift my sword against the breast of him, who has given me such just, such strong, and such repeated reasons, to admire, and love him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It was Florio, my comrade in arms, my bosom-friend, whom I design'd to serve; not that disloyal man, who has invaded my honour, and my love.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Mean, treacherous artifice! to do so gross an injury yourself, then charge me as the wronger! I swear, by all those powers, who both discern, and punish, I never knew that you pretended to Henriquez' sister, till since I came within these fatal walls.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How am I to believe you can speak truth in this, who have myself been witness of your falshood to her?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I false to Honoria! take heed, Antonio, so foul an injury I cannot brook.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Rare confidence! have I not myself assisted your feign'd passion, and been witness of your faithless vows pledg'd to another?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Another! what mean device has bred so strange a charge? but dars't thou talk of violated truth? where are those ardent, sacred, and eternal vows, pledg'd to an unknown fair, with which, at our first interview this night, thou did'st abuse my credulous ear, and taught my sympathising heart, torn as it was with it's own griefs, to throb with pangs for thee?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Still written here;—base man, I cannot longer bear thy mean evasions; either renounce all claim to Honoria, or this must speak the rest.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I'll be reduc'd to atoms, ere I yield her.
sp.stage: Enter HENRIQUEZ, JUAN, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Ay this is well—he shall not 'scape, without some marks of my revenge.
sp.stage: Florio, Antonio turns in his Defence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hold sir; he shall not be o'erpower'd with numbers neither; my honour you invade anew, and wake my pre-engagement to protect him.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Flames and the devil! why were not you yourself doing your best to kill him?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis true; but if he must fall, he shall not be massacred by odds, but conquer'd fairly like a man.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: For heaven's sake, cease this violence; I'll dye for't, but some cursed error lies conceal'd, that thus misleads us all.—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: With my sword alone I'll search it out, tho' multitudes oppos'd me.
sp.stage: [He attacks again, Rosa peeping at the door, cries out Ladies! Ladies!
Enter HONORIA, FELICIA, and ROSA running.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Hear us! hear us!

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: By heavens, Honoria!

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Why did not I tell you she was brought here by my direction?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Oh! thou vile woman! that I cou'd destroy thy memory with thy life!
sp.stage: [He advances furiously towards Honoria; Antonio, Juan, and Florio interpose.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hold, sir;—altho' I do not know this lady, I have, this night, engag'd my faith both to protect, and serve her.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: See there! he does not know Honoria.—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Not know her! why 'tis not an hour, since I saw him entertaining her at my house; death! all we see is illusion, and all we do inchantment!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Suffer me, Don Henriquez, to unspel these charms—Antonio, which of us is it, you pretend to?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Which? how can you ask? you know too well the conquest, which you made of my poor heart, in Flanders.—

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Conquest! heart! and Flanders? what means that now?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: More riddles every moment!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Your contract with Honoria then—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Here I confirm it—when I forego so dear a tye, or wed another fair—

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Take heed, for I am not Honoria.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Not Honoria!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is't possible? have I been only mock'd with visionary bliss, and are my hopes thus blasted?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: All now depends on whatsoever turn Henriquez' temper takes—Observe his conduct, nor doubt of mine.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Astonishment, and disappointed fury seem to possess my brother's thoughts.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I'll try to calm them.—Know, Don Henriquez, that Don Florio has ever been your sister's constant lover, his private visits, at our house, which have disturb'd your peace, were by me calculated for their interview, after you had refus'd her to his addresses;—my heart was then entirely free; 'tis now engag'd:—if I trespass too far on that reserve, which is our sex's ornament, and guard, let the present exigence, and my gratitude for signal services, plead my excuse, while I declare, it is to that brave officer.—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Humph!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: This, brother, is that generous commander, whose valiant arm restor'd our liberties, and who engag'd himself the guardian of my honour.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: This that gallant leader, to whom we are so much indebted?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Why did you not inform me sooner of so laudable a prepossession?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: My dear brother, gratitude, esteem, and a thousand nameless passions, so soon possess'd me, I was asham'd of what you might have call'd a visionary love, and durst not trust my own tongue with my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Your sister, and this lady, Don Henriquez, both can witness I never had a thought to injure your happiness, or honour. Don Pedro's death was occasion'd by your mistaken jealousy; and you well know, (but that your self, and your domesticks, were the only witnesses of that transaction) I had the fairest claim to the protection of the law, having been surpris'd at dis-advantage and oppress'd by numbers.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Pedro deserv'd his death, and I am blameless.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: My shame! my eternal shame! what shall I say? you see me overwhelm'd with confusion; if I have acted in a manner unbecoming my name, and honour, attribute it to love—(I seek not longer to conceal it,) a hurt, a desperate, jealous love for that ungrateful creature.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p:
Cousin, I will now own, I have perceiv'd it long; and in justice to our friendship, and alliance, have even address'd my sister on the subject; but found such insurmountable objections to your but
violence of temper, that, in consideration of what your pride might suffer, I conceal'd my knowledge of your passion, even from yourself.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: How cou'd a man of Don Henriquez' sense, and penetration, suppose his tyrannic treatment of so amiable a sister, such everlasting doubts, suspicions, jealousies, restrictions, and severities, must not disgust rather than win a woman's heart? Cou'd you but have subdued those passions, perhaps, ere I had seen that gentleman, I might have been induc'd to think of you in such a light, as your person, and natural endowments deserv'd; if a disappointment herein be painful, to your self alone you are indebted for it.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Forbear, I pray you; shew not the happiness I might have reached, nor add the weight of your reproaches, to my self-condemnation; my punishment is sufficient without it;—I have justly railed; when such a heart as mine concedes, the pangs it suffers are not trivial.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I am sorry, and ask pardon.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Yet to convince you that my sorrow is not selfish; as I have been the source of general uneasiness, I will endeavour to make a general amends, let my own heart suffer what it may: first madam, may you enjoy more happiness, if possible, than I have wish'd to partake with you; and, sir, to you, unask'd I thus resign this contract, which love and justice both forbid me now to claim,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Noble Henriquez; I thank and honour you.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Sir, take from me her hand, whose heart your worth, and bravery has merited.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Thus I receive the sum of happiness, this world can give; and, sir, since you have generously resign'd the name of brother, allow me that of friend, which while I live I will deserve; and suffer
me to entreat your concurrence for your sister's happiness, where destiny seems to lead;—I will answer, with my life, my friend will merit her.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Sir, she is your's;—and here dies all my animosity.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: We are now all your debtors; I am peculiarly so.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: My brother, now you are indeed my brother; noble, generous, and kind, you have set my heart at ease, and I am myself again.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: That's more than I am, I'm sure; I have seen so many wonders, I shan't be myself again this twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: They have had a rare come-off; sure, 'twou'd make a good plot for a play.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: That wou'd be bad for me; for, by the laws of comedy, I should be oblig'd to marry you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Well thought of, Guzman, tho' spoke in jest; you seem well fitted for each other, and your faithful services deserve our general encouragement; what say you Rosa?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Sir, I say I have had so many frights to night, I am e'en afraid to lye alone.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Thy hand, sweet Rosa; 'tis a bargain; if I dont repent first, I don't care.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: This union being in my house, let me entreat your stay, to unite in woad'ring at these events, and enjoying general congratulations; cousin you will not refuse me?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p:
I will not be a means to thwart your mirth, but endeavour, as well as I am able, to partake it,—my heart has now a new, a difficult, and painful lesson set it, but it must be learn'd; for our adventures prove that womens mild and gentle hearts must be sooth'd by indulgence, not frighted
by severity; and that easy, frank, and confiding tempers bid fairest for a generous return,
sp.l: Since such, and such alone, deserve to share
The confidence, and favour of the fair.

lg.l: AY!—ay!—they're at it—in a dainty tew;
"Have you the Epilogue?"—"Not I—" have you?
(Miss Macklin and Miss Wilford there I mean)
"I!—I don't know that any has been seen".
"Lud! where's the author?—I'm in such a fright!
"The author, child?—not ventur'd here to-night."
"What shall we do, my dear?"—"I cannot guess"—
To palliate this ridiculous distress,
Will you permit me to apologize
For this hard tax on new form'd comedies?—
In short these Epilogues are grown so trite,
So few the subjects left, whereon to write,
So few the authors with this knack endued,
Perhaps my nonsense may be quite as good.
I've been in front—and, if with leave I may,
I'll give my inferences from this play.
See Mr. Garrick's Epilogue to the Earl of Warwick. The beauteous Marg'ret of the Rival-House,
To lower the grandeur of despotic spouse,
Has taught the ladies, in true comic vein,
Rules to maintain, and use, their pow'r o'er men.
My hints (altho' in homelier style than those)
To you, ye Lords of Nature, I'll disclose.
Would you, high Potentates, throughout your lives,
Preserve obedient sisters, daughters, wives,
Avoid Henriquez' faults—be never proud,
Distrustful, jealous, arrogant, or loud;
Where e'er we go, what e'er we do, or say,
Make it your rule—to give us our own way;
Neither attempt to lead us, nor restrain,
But let us have the length of all the rein;
In shoppings, auctions, jauntings, or Quadrille,
Leave us to spend, and lose what e'er we will;
Let all our fav'rite foibles take their course,
(For every breather has some hobby-horse)
With whatsoever whims or freaks you meet,
Still let your words and looks alike be sweet—
Lord! when thus left to our own tempers free,
The sweetest creatures in the world are we!—
Hence this important Maxim is defin'd,
Ye wise ones, keep it ever in your mind—
We women never frown, if never teaz'd,
And, always humour'd,—we are always pleas'd.
